titleStmt.author: Heywood, Thomas, d. 1641.

publicationStmt.publisher: Printed by Nicholas Okes for Iohn Iackson and Francis Church, and are to be sold at the Kings Armes in Cheape-side,

div.p: A Pleasant Comedy, called A MAYDEN-HEAD WELL LOST. As it hath beene publickly Acted at the Cocke-pit in Drury-lane, with much Applause: By her Maiesties Seruants.
LONDON, Printed by Nicholas Okes for Iohn Iackson and Francis Church, and are to be sold at the Kings Armes in Cheape-side. 1634.

div.head: To the Reader.
div.p:
COurteous Reader, (of what sexe soeuer) let not the Title of this Play any way deterre thee from the perusall thereof: For there is nothing herein contained, which doth deuiate either from Modesty, or good Manners. For though the Argument be drawne from a Mayden-head lost, yet to be well lost, cleares it from all aspersion. Neither can this be drawne within the Criticall censure of that most horrible Histriomastix, whose vncharitable doome hauing damned all such to the flames of Hell, hath it selfe already suffered a most remarkeable fire here vpon Earth. This hath beene frequently, and publickly Acted without exception, and I presume may be freely read without distaste; and of all in generall: excepting such, whose prepared palats, disgusting all Poems of this nature, are poysoned with the bitter iuice of that Coloquintida and Hemlocke, which can neither relish the peace of the
Church nor Common-weale. Nothing remaineth further to be said, but read charitably, and then censure without preiudice.
By him who hath beene euer studious of thy fauour,

list.item: Mounsieur, the Tutor to the Prince.

div.head: The Prologue.
div.l: PRologues to Playes in vse, and common are,
As Vshers to Great Ladies: Both walke bare,
And comely both; conducting Beauty they
And wee appeare, to vsher in our Play.
Yet, be their faces foule, or featur'd well,
Be they hard-fauoured, or in lookes excell;
Yet being Vsher, he owes no lesse duty
Vnto the most deformed, then the choise Beautie.
It is our case; we vsher Acts and Scenes,
Some honest, and yet some may proue like Queanes.
(Loose and base stuffe) yet that is not our fault,
We walke before, but not like Panders hault
Before such cripled ware: Th' Acts we present
We hope are Virgins, drawne for your content
Vnto this Stage: Maides gratefull are to Men,
Our Scenes being such, (like such) accept them then.

div.head: Actus primus, Scena prima.

sp.speaker: Iulia.
sp.l: THat shee should doo't?

sp.speaker: Stroza.
sp.l: Shee?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: May we build vpon't?

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: As on a base of Marble; I haue seene
Strange passages of loue, loose enterchanges
Of hands and eyes betwixt her and the Prince,
Madama looke too't.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: What hope hath he in one
So meanly bred? or shee t'obtaine a Prince
Of such discent and linnage?

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: What but this
That you must vndergoe the name of wife,
And she to intercept the sweetes of loue
Due to your bed.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: To be his strumpet Stroza?

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Madame a woman may guesse vnhappily.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Thou shouldst be honest Stroza.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Yes, many should
Be what they are not: but I alwayes was,
And euer will be one, (that's still my selfe.)

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: The Generall Sforsaes daughter? is't not she?

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Is that yet questioned? as if the chaste Court
Had saue her selfe one so degenerate,
So dissolutely wanton, so profuse
In prostitution too, so impudent
And blushlesse in her proud ambitious aime,
As if no man could her intemperance please,
Saue him whom Heauen hath destin'd to your bed.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: I neuer saw them yet familiar.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Ha, ha, as if they'd send for you to see't,
To witnesse what they most striue to conceale,
Be guld? be branded: ' lasto me, all's nothing,
I shall ne're smart for't, what is't to me?
If being a Bride, you haue a widdowed fortune;
If being married, you must throw your selfe
Vpon a desolate bed, and in your armes,
Claspe nought but Ayre, whilst his armes full of pleasure
Borrow'd from a stolne beauty, shall this grieue
Or trouble me? breake my sleepes? make me starte
At midnight vp, and fill the house with clamours?
Shall this bring strange brats to be bred and brought
Vp at my fire, and call me Dad? No: this
Concernes not me more then my loue to you
To your high Soueraignty.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: I now repent
Too late, since I too lauishly haue giuen him
The vtmost he could aske, and stretcht my honour
Beyond all lawfull bounds of modesty.
Hee's couetous of others, and neglects
His owne; but I will part those their stolne pleasures,
And crosse those lustfull sports they haue in chase,
Not be the pillow to my owne disgrace.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: The game's on foote, and there's an easie path
To my reuenge; this beauteous Millanois
Vnto th'Duke sole heire, still courted, crau'd,
And by the Parma Prince sollicited,
Which I still study how to breake, and cast
Aspersions betwixt both of strange dislike;
But wherein hath the other innocent Mayde
So iniur'd me, that I should scandall her?
Her Father is the Generall to the Duke:
For when I studdied to be rais'd by Armes,
And purchase me high eminence in Campe,
He crost my fortunes, and return'd me home
A Cashierd Captaine; for which iniury
I scandall all his meanes vnto the Duke,
And to the Princesse all his daughters vertues,
I labour to inuert, and bring them both
Into disgracefull hatred.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Stroza?

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: My Lord?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Saw you the Princesse?

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Iulia?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: She?

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: I haue my Lord of late no eare of hers,
Nor she a tongue of mine; the, time hath bin
Till soothing Sycophantsand Court Parasites
Supplanted me.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: I haue the power with her
To bring thee into grace.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Haue you the power
To keepe your selfe in? doe you smile my Lord?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: I tell thee Stroza, I haue that interest
In Iulias bosome, that the proudest Prince
In Italy cannot supplant me thence.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Sir,
Ino way question it: but haue I not knowne
A Prince hath bin repulst, and meanest persons
Bosom'd? the Prince would once haue lookt vpon me,
When small intreaty would haue gain'd an eye,
An eare, a tongue, to speake yea, and a heart,
To thinke I could be secret.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: What meanes Stroza?

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: But 'tis the fate of all mortality:
Man cannot long be happy; but my passion
Will make me turne blab, I shall out with all.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Whence comes this? 'tis suspicious, and I must be
Inquisitiue to know't.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: A Iest my Lord,
I'le tell you a good Iest.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Prithee let's heare it.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: What will you say, if at your meeting next
With this faire Princesse? shee begins to raue,
To raile vpon you, to exclaime on your
Inconstancy, and call the innocent name
Of some chaste Maide in question, whom perhaps
You neuer ey'd my Lord.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: What of all this?

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: What but to excuse her owne: (I'le not say what)
Put off the purpos'd Contract: and my Lord
Come, come, I know you haue a pregnant wit.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: We parted last with all the kindest greeting
Louers could adde fare-well with: but should this change
Suite thy report, I should be forc't to thinke
That, which cuen Oracles themselues could neuer
Force me to that she is.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: All women are not
Sincerely constant, but obserue my Lord.

div.stage: Enter Iulia, the Generals Wife, and Lauretta her Daughter.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Minion is't you? there's for you, know your owne.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Obseru'd you that my Lord?
sp.stage: Inlia meets her and strikes her, then speakes.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Why did you strike me Madame?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Strumpet, why?
Dare you contest with vs?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Who dare with Princesse? subiects must forbeare
Each step I treade I'le water with a teare.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: I spy a storme a comming, Ile to shelter.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Your meaning Madame?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Did it Sir with yours
But correspond, it would be bad indeede.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Why did you strike that Lady?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Cause you should pitty her.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Small cause for blowes.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: I strucke her publickly.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: You giue her blowes in priuate.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Stroza still?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Goe periurd and dispose thy false allurements
'Mongst them that will beleeue thee, thou hast lost
Thy credit here for euer.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: I shall finde
Faith else-where then.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Eye spread thy snares
To catch poore innocent Maides: and hauing tane them
In the like pit-fall, with their shipwrackt honours,
Make seasure of their liues.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Iniurious Lady,
All thou canst touch my Honour with, I cast
On thee, and henceforth I will flye thee as
A Basaliske. I haue found the change of lust,
Your loose inconstancy, which is as plaine
To me, as were it writ vpon thy brow,
You shall not cast me off: I hate thy sight,
And from this houre I will abiure thee quite.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Ile call him backe: if Stroza be no villaine,
He is not worth my clamour. What was that startled
Within me? Oh I am dishonoured
Perpetually; for he hath left behinde
That pledge of his acquaintance, that will for euer
Cleaue to my blood in scandall, I must now
Sue, send, and craue, and what before I scorn'd
By prayers to grant, submissiuely implore.

div.stage: A flourish. Enter the Duke of Millenie, the Generals wife, and deliuers apetition with Stroza, Lauretta, and attendants.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Lady your suite?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: So please your Grace peruse it,
It is included there.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: Our generals Wife?

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: We know you Lady, and your beauteous Daughter,
Nay you shall spare your knee,

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: More plot for mee;
My brain's in labour, and must be deliuered
Of some new mischeife?

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: You petition heere
For Men and Money I making a free relation
Of all your Husbands fortunes, how supplyes
Haue beene delay'd, and what extremities
He hath indurd at Naples dreadfull Seige;
We know them all, and withall doe acknowledge
All plentious blessings by the power of Heauen,
By him wee doe obtaine, and by his valour
Lady we greue he hath beene so neglected.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: O Roiall Sir, you still were Gratious,
But twixt your Vertues and his Merits there
Hath beene some interception, that hath stopt
The current of your fauours.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: All which shal bee remou'd, and hee appeare
Henceforth a bright starre in our courtly spheare.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: But no such Comet here shall daze my sight,
Whilst I a Cloud am to Eclips that light

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: We sent out our Commissions two Monthes since
For Men and Money, nor was't our intent
It should bee thus delayd: though we are Prince,
We onely can command, to Execute
Tis not in vs but in our Officers,
We vnderstand that by their negligence
He has beene put to much extremity
Of Dearth and Famine; many a stormy night
Beene forc'd to roofe himselfe i'th open field,
Nay more then this, much of his owne reuenue
He hath expended, all to pay his Souldiers:
Yet Reuerend Madame, but forget what's past,
Though late, weele quit his merit at the last.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Your Highnesse is most Royall?

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: Her Father shall be in the Campe releiu'd,
She grac'd in Court, how will she braue you then?
If suffer this take all? why the meanest Lady
Would neuer brooke an equall? you a Princesse?
And can you brooke a base competitor?

sp.speaker: Iulia
sp.l: It shall not, we are fixt and stand immou'd,
And will be swaid by no hand.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: Iulia?

sp.speaker: Iulia.
sp.l: A Sutor to that Lady Royall Father,
Before she be a widdow that you are
So priuate in discourse?

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: O you mistake,
For shee the sutor is and hath obtain'd.

sp.speaker: Iulia.
sp.l: I'm glad I haue found you in the giuing vaine
Will you grant me one boone to?

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: Question not,
To hast your Marriage with the former Prince,
Or at the least the contract, is't not that?

sp.speaker: Iulia.
sp.l: Say twere my Lord?

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: It could not be denide
But speake? thy suite?

sp.speaker: Iulia.
sp.l: To haue this modest Gentlewoman
Banisht the Court,

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: My Daughter Royall princesse,
Show vs some cause I beg it?

sp.speaker: Iulia.
sp.l: Lady though
You be i'th begging vaine, I am not now
In the giuing, will you leaue vs?

sp.speaker: Lauretta.
sp.l: Wherein O Heauen
Haue I deseru'd your wrath, that you should thus
Persue me? I haue searcht, indeed beyond
My vnderstanding, but yet cannot finde?
Wherein I haue offended by my chastity.

sp.speaker: Iulia.
sp.l: How chastitiy?
A thing long sought 'mongst Captains wiues and daughters,
Yet hardly can bee found.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: Faier Lady yeild
Vnto my daughters spleen her rage blowne 'ore,
Feare not, Ile make your peace, as for your suite
Touching your husband, that will I secure.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Haste Stroza, vnto the Prince his chamber,
Giue him this letter, it concernes my honor,
My state, my life, all that I can call good
Depends vpon the safe deliuery
Of these few broken Letters.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Maddam, tis done—

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: What stayes she to out-face me?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Madam, I yeeld
Way to your spleene, not knowing whence it growes,
Bearing your words more heauy then your blowes.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Small hope there is to see the Father righted.
When the child is thus wrong'd.

sp.speaker: Soul.
sp.l: Must speake with the Duke,

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Must fellow? stay your howre, and dance attendance
Vntill the Duke's at leisure.

sp.speaker: Soul.
sp.l: Ile doe neither,
I come in haste with newes,

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Why then keepe out sir.

sp.speaker: Soul.
sp.l: Ha Milksop? know percullist gates
Though kept with Pikes & Muskets, could nere kepe me out
And dost thou thinke to shut me out with Wainscot?

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: What's he?

sp.speaker: Soul.
sp.l: A Souldier,

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: Whence?

sp.speaker: Soul.
sp.l: The Campe

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: The newes?

sp.speaker: Soul.
sp.l: A mighty losse; a glorious victory

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: But which the greater?

sp.speaker: Soul.
sp.l: Tis vncertaine Sir:
But will you heare the best or bad newes first?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Cheere me with conquest first, that being arm'd
With thy best newes, we better may endure
What sounds more fatall.

sp.speaker: Soul.
sp.l: Heare me then my Lord,
We sack't the Citty after nine Moneths siege,
Furnisht with store of all warres furniture,
Our (neuer to be praisd enough) braue Generall
Fought in the Cannons face, their number still
Increast, but our diminisht; their souldiers pay
Doubled, and ours kept backe: but we (braue spirits)
The losse we had of Coyne, the more we tooke
Vnto our selues of Courage, but when all
Our furniture was spent euen to one day,
And that to morrow we must be inforc't
To raise a shameful siege, then stood our General
(Our valiant Generall) vp, and breath'd vpon vs
His owne vndaunted spirit, which spred through
The Campe, return'd it doubly arm'd againe:
For he did meane to lay vpon one shott
His state and fortune, and then instantly
He bad vs arme and follow: On then he went,
We after him; oh! 'twas a glorious sight,
Fit for a Theater of Gods to see,
How we made vp and mauger all opposure,
Made way through raging stormes of showring bullets;
At last we came to hooke our ladders, and
By them to skale. The first that mounted, was
Our bold couragious Generall: after him
Ten thousand, so we instantly were made
Lords of the Citty, purchas'd in two houres
After a nine Moneths siege: all by the valour
Of our approued Generall.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: I neuer heard a brauer victory,
But what's our losse?

sp.speaker: Soul.
sp.l: Oh that, which ten such Conquests
Cannot make good, your worthy Generall.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: My Lord and husband? spare me passion,
I must with-draw to death.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: How perish't he?
What dy'de he by the sword?

sp.speaker: Soul.
sp.l: Sword? No alas,
No sword durst byte vpon his noble flesh,
Nor bullet raze his skinne: he whom War feared,
The Cannon spar'd, no steele durst venture on.
No Duke, 'twas thy vnkinde ingratitude
Hath slaine braue Sforsa.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Speake the cause?

sp.speaker: Soul.
sp.l: I shall:
This Citty seaz'd, his purpose was the spoyle
To giue his Souldiers; but when his seal'd Commission
He had vnript, and saw expresse command,
To deale no farther then to victory,
And that his great Authority was curb'd,
And giuen to others, that respect their profit
More then the worth of souldiers: euen for griefe,
That he could neither furnish vs with pay
Which was kept back, nor guerdon vs with spoile,
What was about him he distributed,
Euen to the best deseruers, as his garments,
His Armes, and Tent, then some few words spake,
And so opprest with griefe, his great heart brake.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: There's one gone then.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Attend for thy reward,
So leaue vs.

sp.speaker: Soul.
sp.l: Pray on whom shall I attend?
Who is't must pay me?

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: I sir.

sp.speaker: Soul.
sp.l: You sir? tell me,
Will it not cost me more the waiting for,
Then the summe comes to when it is receiu'd?
I doe but aske the question.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: You are a bold
And saucy souldier.

sp.speaker: Soul.
sp.l: You are a cunning slaue,
And cowardly Courtier.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: See all things be dispatcht
Touching conditions of attoned peace
'Twixt vs and Naples: see that souldier to
Haue his reward.

sp.speaker: Soul.
sp.l: Come will you pay me sir?

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Sir, will you walke: as for your saucinesse
I'le teach you a Court-tricke: you shal be taught
How to attend.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: But that our General's lost:

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Is't not now peace, what should a Generall doe?
Had he return'd, he would haue lookt for honours,
This suite and that for such a follower:
Now Royall sir, that debt is quite discharg'd.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: But for his wife, we must be mindefull of her,
And see we doe so.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Speake, will he come?

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Madam, I found him ready to depart
The Court with expedition: but at my vrgence
He promis't you a parley.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: It is well:
If prayers or teares can moue him, Ile make way
To saue my owne shame, and enforce his stay.

div.stage: Enter three souldiers: one without an arme.

sp.speaker: 1 Soul.
sp.l: Come fellow souldiers, doe you know the reason
That we are summon'd thus vnto the house
Of our dead Generall?

sp.speaker: 2 Soul.
sp.l: Sure 'tis about
Our pay.

sp.speaker: 3 Soul.
sp.l: But stand aside, here comes the Lady.

div.stage: Enter the Mother, Lauretta, and Clowne.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Are all these Gentlemen summond together,
That were my Husbands followers, and whose fortunes
Expir'd in him?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: They are if please your Ladiship: though I was neuer Tawny-coate, I haue playd the summoners part, and the rest are already paide, onely these three attend your Ladiships remuneration.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Welcome Gentlemen,
My Husband led you on to many dangers
Two yeares, and last to pouerty: His reuenewes
Before hand he sold to maintaine his Army,
When the Dukes pay still fail'd, you know you were
Stor'd euer from his Coffers.

sp.speaker: 1 Soul.
sp.l: He was a right
And worthy Generall.

sp.speaker: 2 Soul.
sp.l: He was no lesse.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: He was no lesse; and all you know hee was no more, well, had he liu'd, I had beene plac't in some house of office or other ere this time.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: It was his will, which to my vtmost power
I will make good, to satisfie his souldiers
To the vtmost farthing. All his Gold and Iewels
I haue already added, yet are we still
To score to souldiery? what is your summe?

sp.speaker: 1 Soul.
sp.l: Pay for three Moneths.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: There's double that in Gold.

sp.speaker: 1 Soul.
sp.l: I thanke your Ladiship.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: What yours?

sp.speaker: 2 Soul.
sp.l: Why Madam,
For foure Moneths pay.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: This Iewell surmounts that.

sp.speaker: 2 Soul.
sp.l: I am treble satisfied.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: You are behinde hand too:

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Ey but Madam, I thinke he be no true souldier.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: No true Souldier your reason?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Marry because he walkes without his Armes.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: The Dukes Treasure
Cannot make good that losse, yet are we rich
In one thing:
Nothing we haue that were of nothing made,
Nothing we haue, my Husbands debts are payd.
Morrow Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Madam, Hearts, Swords and hands, rest still
At your command.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Gentlemen I'me sorry that I cannot pay you better,
Vnto my wishes and your owne desert,
'Tis plainely seene great Persons oft times fall,
And the most Rich cannot giue more then all.
Good morrow Gentlemen,

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: May you be euer happy.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: I but Madam, this is a hard case being truly considered, to giue away all, why your Shoe-maker, though he hath many other Tooles to worke with, he will not giue away his All.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: All ours was his alone, it came by him.
And for his Honour it was paid againe.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Why, say I had a peece of Meate, I had a mind to, I might perhaps giue away a Modicum, a Morcell, a Fragment or so, but to giue away and bee a hungry my selfe, I durst not doo't for my Guts, or say I should meete with a friend that had but one Penny in his Purse, that should giue mee a Pot of Ale, that should drinke to me, and drinke vp all, I'le stand too't there's no Conscience in't.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: What hath beene done was for my Fathers Honor.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Shee might haue giuen away a little, and a little, but
When all is gone, what's left for me?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Wee will leaue Millaine and to Florence straight,
Though wee are poore, yet where we liue vnknowne
'Tis the lesse griefe, sirrah, will you consort
With vs, and beare a part in our misfortunes?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Troth Madam, I could find in my heart to goe with you but for one thing.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: What's that?

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: Because you are too liberall a Mistresse: and that's a fault seldome found among Ladies: For looke, you vse o giue away all, and I am all that is left; and I am affraide when you come into a strange Countrey, you'le giue away me too, so that I shall neuer liue to be my owne man.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Tush, feare it not.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.l: Why then I'le goe with you inspite of your teeth.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Leaue Milleine then, to Florence be our guide,
Heauen when man failes, must for our helpe prouide.

div.head: Actus Secundus, Scena prima.
div.stage: Enter Parma reading a Letter: after him Iulia.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: This Letter came from you, 'tis your Character.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: That hand in Contract you so long haue had,
Should not seeme strange to you now.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: You are with-childe,
So doth your Letter say: what change your face?

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: My blushes must speake for me.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: And this Childe
You would bestow on me: you are very liberall Lady,
You giue me more then I did meane to aske.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: And yet but what's your owne Sir, I am serious,
And it will ill become your Oathes and Vowes
To iest at my vndoeing.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: You would say
Rather your doing.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: In doing thus, you should vndoe me quite.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: What doe you weepe, that late did rayle in clamor?
Your thunders turnd to showres? It is most strange.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: You haue dishonoured me, and by your flattery
Haue rob'd me of my chaste Virginity:
Yet ere I yeelded, we were man and wife,
Sauing the Churches outward Ceremony.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: But Lady, you that would be wonne by me
To such an act of lust, would soone consent
Vnto another.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Can this be found in man?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: This Strozas language moues me, and I intend
To try what patience, constancy, and loue
There can be found in woman: why do you weepe?
You are not hungry, for your bellie's full;
Lady, be rul'd by me: take the aduice
A Doctor gaue a Gentleman of ate,
That sent to him to know, whether Tobacco
Were good for him or no: My friend quoth he,
If thou didst neuer loue it, neuer take it;
If thou didst euer loue it, neuer leaue it:
So I to thee; if thou wert as thou hast
Beene alwayes honest, I could wish thee still
So to continue; but being a broken Lady,
Your onely way's to make vse of your Talent,
Farewell, I'le to my Countrey.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Oh miserable,
Let me but reckon vp ten thousand ills
My loosenesse hath committed, the aspersion
And scandalous reputation of my Childe,
My Father too, 'tmust come vnto his care,
Oh—

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Iulia.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Away.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Come hither, but one word.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: That all those blacke occurrents should conspire,
And end in my disgrace.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Ha! what's the businesse?

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: If all men were such,
I should be sorry that a man begot me,
Although he were my father.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Iulia, how's that?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Oh Sir, you come to know whether Tobacco be good for you or no; Ile tell you, if you neuer tooke it, neuer take it then, or it you euer vs'd it, take it still; Nay, I'me an excellent Philistian growne of late I tell you.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: What meane these strange Anagrams?
I am thy Father and I loue thee sweete.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Loue me thou dost not.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Why thou doest know I doe.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: I say thou doest not: lay no wager with me,
For if thou dost, there will be two to one
On my side against thee.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Ha! I am thy Father
Why Iulia?

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: How my Father! then doe one thing
For me your Daughter

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: One thing? any thing,
Ey all things.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Instantly then draw your sword
And pierce me to the heart.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: I loue thee not so ill,
To be the Author of thy death.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Nor I my selfe so well, as to desire
A longer life: if you be then my Father,
Punish a sinne that hath disgrac't your Daughter,
Scandald your blood, and poyson'd it with mud.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Be plaine with vs.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: See, I am strumpeted,
A bastard issue growes within my wombe.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Whose fact?

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Prince Parmaes.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Stroza.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: My Lord.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Search out
Prince Parma, bring the Traytour backe againe
Dead or aliue.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: My Lord, he is a Prince.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: No matter; for his head shall be the ransome
Of this foule Treason. When I say begon.
But as for thee base and degenerate—

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Doe shew your selfe a Prince: let her no longer
Liue, that hath thus disgrac't your Royall Blood.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Nature preuailes 'boue honour: her offence
Merits my vengeance, but the name of Childe
Abates my Swords keene edge: yet Royalty
Take th'vpper hand of pitty: kill the strumpet,
And be renown'd for Iustice.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Strike, I'le stand.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: How easie could I period all my care,
Could I her kill, and yet her Infant spare:
A double Murder I must needes commit,
To ruine that which neuer offended yet.
Oh Heauen! in this I your assistance craue,
Punish the faulter, and the innocent saue.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: You are not true to your owne honour Father.
To let me longer liue.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Oh Iulia, Iulia,
Thou hast ouerwhelm'd vpon my aged head
Mountaines of griefe, t'oppresse me to my graue.
Is Parma found?

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: My Lord, hee's priuately
Fled from the Court

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Then flye thou after villaine.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Sir, are you madde?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: What's to be done? Alacke,
I cannot change a father and a Prince
Into a euiell Hang-man: tell me Iulia,
Is thy guilt yet but priuate to thy selfe?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: It is my Lord.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Conceale it then: wee'le study
To salue thy honour, and to keepe thy loosenesse
From all the world conceal'd, compresse thy griefe,
And I will study how to shadow mine.
Wipe from thy cheekes these teares: oh cursed Age,
When Children 'gainst their Parents all things dare,
Yet Fathers still proue Fathers in their care.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.l: Oh misery beyond comparison!
When saue the Heauens we haue no roofe at all
To shelter vs.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: That word all
Stickes more in my stomacke then my victuals can: For indeede wee can get none to eate now; I told you, you were so prodiga'l we should pinch for't.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.l: What place may wee call this? what Clime? what Prouince?

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: Why this is the Duke-dome of Florence, and this is the Forrest where the hard-hearted Duke hunts many a Hart: and there's no Deere so deare to him, but hee'le kill it: as goodly a large place to starue in, as your Ladiship can desire to see in a Summers day.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.l: Yet here, since no man knowes vs, no man can
Deride our misery: better dye staru'd,
Then basely begge.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: How better starue then begge; all the Ladies of Florence shal neuer make me of that beleefe. I had rather beg a thousand times, then starue once, doe you scorne begging? Your betters doe not, no Madam; get me a Snap-sacke, I'le to Florence: I'le make all the high wayes ring of me with for the Lords sake. I haue studied a Prayer for him that giues, and a Poxe take him that giues nothing: I haue one for the Horse-way, another for the Foote-way, and a third for the turning-ftile. No Madam, begging is growne a gentleman-like Calling here in our Countrey.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.l: I haue yet one poore piece of Gold reseru'd,
Step to the Village by and fetch some Wine.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p:
You had better keepe your Gold, and trust to my begging Oratory, yet this is the worst they can say to mee,
that I am my Ladies Bottle-man.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.l: Here's a strange change: we must be patient,
Yet can I not but weepe thinking on thee.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Madam on me? there is no change of Fortune
Can puffe me or deiect me; I am all one
In rich abundance and penurious want:
So little doe my miseries vexe me,
Or the faire Princesse wrong, that I will end
My passions in a Song.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.l: It seemes the Duke is Hunting in the Forrest,
Here let vs rest our selues, and listen to
Their Tones, for nothing but mishap here lies;
Sing thou faire Childe, I'le keepe tune with my eyes.

div.stage: Winde hornes. And enter the Prince of Florence & Mounsieur.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: This way the voyce was, let vs leaue the Chace.

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.l: Behold my Lord two sad deiected Creatures
Throwne on the humble verdure.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: Here's beauty mixt with teares, that pouerty
Was neuer bred in Cottage: I'le farther question
Their state and fortune.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.l: Wee're discouered,
Daughter arise.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: What are you gentle Creatures?
Nay answere not in teares.
If you by casuall losse, or by the hand
Of Fortune haue beene crusht beneath these sorrowes,
He demands your griefe
That hath as much will as ability
To succour you, and for your owne faire sake;
Nay beautious Damsell, you neede not question that.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: If by the front we may beleeue the heart,
Or by the out-side iudge the inward vertue:
You faire Sir, haue euen in your selfe alone
All that this world can promise; for I ne're
Beheld one so compleate; and were I sure
Although you would not pitty, yet at least
You would not mocke our misery: I would relate
A Tale should make you weepe.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: Sweete if the Prologue
To thy sad passion mooue thus: what will the Sceane
And tragicke act it selfe doe? Is thatt Gentlewoman
Your Mother sweete?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: My wretched Mother Sir.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: Pray of what Prouince?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Milleine.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: What fortune there?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: My Father was a Noble Gentleman,
Rank't with the best in Birth, and which did adde
To all his other vertues, a bold Souldier;
But when he dy'de—

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: Nay, proceede beauteous Lady,
How was your Father stil'd?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: To tell you that,
Were to exclaime vpon my Prince, my Countrey
And their Ingratitude: For he being dead,
With him our fortunes and our hopes both fail'd;
My Mother loath to liue ignobly base,
Where once she flourisht, hauing spent her meanes
Not loosely nor in riot, but in the honour
Of her dead Husband: left th'ingratefull Land,
Rather to spend her yeares in pouerty,
Mongst those that neuer knew her height of Fortune,
Then with her thankelesse Friends and Countrey-men,
Fled here to perish.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: More then her Charming beauty
Her passion moues me: where inhabit you?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Here, euery where.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: Beneath these Trees?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: We haue
No other roofe then what kinde Heauen lends.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: Gentle Creature,
Had you not told me that your Birth was Noble,
I should haue found it in your face and gesture.
Mounsieur.

sp.speaker: Mounsieur
sp.l: My Lord.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: Goe winde thy Horne abroad, and call to vs
Some of our traine: we pitty these two Ladies,
And we will raise thier hope: Cheere you old Madam,
You shall receiue some bounty from a Prince.
Who keepes the Lodge below?

sp.speaker: Hunts.
sp.l: Your Highnesse Hunts-man.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: Command him to remoue, and instantly
We giue it to these Ladies: besides, adde
Vnto our Guest three thousand pounds a yeare:
We'le see it furnisht too with Plate and Hangings.
'Las pretyt Maide, your father's dead you say,
We'le take you now to our owne Patronage,
And trust me Lady, whiel wee're Prince of Florence,
You shall not want nor foode, nor harborage.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.l: Pardon Great Sir, this our neglect of duty
Vnto a Prince so gracious and compleate
In vertuous indowments.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: To excuse
Our former negligence, behold I cast
Me at your foote.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: Arise sweete, pray your name?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Lauretta.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: Faire Lauretta, you shall be henceforth ours,
Oh Mounsieur! I ne're saw where I could loue
Till now.

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.l: How now my Lord, remember pray,
What you are to this poore deiected Maide.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: Well Mounsieur, well; when e're I match, pray Heauen,
We loue so well: but loue and toyle hath made vs
Euen somewhat thirsty, would we had some Wine.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.l: Nay, now I thinke I haue fitted you with a Cup of
Nipsitato.

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.l: How now sirrah, what are you?

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.l: What am I? Nay what art thou?
I thinke you le proue little better then a smell-smocke,
That can finde out a pretty wench in such a Corner.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.l: Peace sirrah, 'tis the Prince.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: What if he be? he may loue a Wench as well as another man.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: What hast thou there?

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: A bottle of Wine and a Manchet that my Lady sent me for.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: Thou ne're couldst come to vs in better time,
Reach it vs Mounsieur.

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.l: Your bottle quickly sirrah, come I say.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: Yes, when? can you tell? doe you thinke I am such an Asse, to part so lightly with my liquor? Know thou my friend, before I could get this bottle fill'd, I was glad to change a piece of Gold, and call for the rest againe. And doe you thinke I'le loose my liquor, and haue no Gold nor rest againe? Not so my Friend, not so.

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.l: There's Gold sir.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.l: Madam, will you giue me a Licence to sell Wine?
I could get no Plate in the Forrest but a woodden Dish.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.l: Fill to the Prince Lauretia.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Will it please
Your Highnesse drinke out of a woodden Mazer?

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: Yes sweete with thee in any thing: you know
Wee are a Prince, and you shall be our taster.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Why should I loue this Prince? his bounteous gifts
Exalt me not, but make me much more poore,
I'me more deiected then I was before.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.l: Sir.

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.l: Lady, thankes: I feare me he is caught,
But if he be, my Counsell must diuert him.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.l: The bottome of the bottle is at your seruice Sir,
Shall you and I part stakes?

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.l: There's more Gold for you.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: I had rather you had broke my pate then my draught, but harke you Sir, are you as a man should say, a belonger to?

sp.speaker: Hunt.
sp.l: A belonger to? what's that sir?

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.l: Oh ignorant! are you a follower?

sp.speaker: Hunt.
sp.l: I seldome goe before when my betters are in place.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.l: A Seruing-man I take it.

sp.speaker: Hunt.
sp.l: Right sir.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: I desire you the more complement: I haue the courtesie of the Forrest for you.

sp.speaker: Hunt.
sp.l: And I haue the courtesie of the Court for you sir.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: That's to bring me to the Buttery hatch, and neuer make me drinke.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: Sirrah, conduct those Ladies to the Lodge,
And tell the Keeper we haue stor'd for him,
A better fortune; you shall heare further from vs,
You vsher them.

sp.speaker: Hunt.
sp.l: Come Ladies will you walke?

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: How now sawce-boxe, know your manners: was not I Gentleman vsher before you came? Am not I hee that did the bottle bring? Come Ladies follow me.

div.stage: Exit Clowne with Ladies, with Huntsman.

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.l: Your purpose Sir, is to loue this Lady,
And hazard all your hopes.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: Oh gentle Friend,
Why was I borne high? but to raise their hopes
That are deiected: so much for my bounty.

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.l: But for your loue.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: It is with no intent
To make the Maide my wife, because I know
Her fortunes cannot equall mine.

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.l: Then 'twere more dishonorable
To strumpet her.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: Still thou mistak'st, mine
Is honourable loue, and built on vertue;
Nor would I for the Emperours Diademe,
Corrupt her whom I loue.

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.l: Braue Prince I'me glad
That ere I kept thy Company.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: Come Mounsieur, night steales on, not many yeares
Shall passe me, but I purpose to reuisite
This my new Mistresse, my auspicious fate
To thee my happy loue I consecrate.

div.stage: A Dumbe show. Enter the Duke of Milleine, a Midwife with a young Childe, and after them Stroza: the Duke shewes the Childe to Stroza, hee takes it: then the Duke sweares them both to secrecy vpon his Sword, and exit with the Midwife: then Stroza goes to hide it, and Parma dogs him: when hee hath laid the Childe in a Corner, he departs in haste, and Parma takes up the Childe and speakes.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Thou shouldst be mind: and durst I for my Head
Euen in the open Court I'de challenge thee.
But I haue so incenst th'offended Duke,
And layd such heauy spots vpon her head,
I cannot doo't wiht safety: methinkes this Child
Doth looke me in the face, as if 'twould call
Me Father, and but this suspected Stroza
Stuft my too credulous eares with iealousies.
For thee sweete Babe I'le sweare, that if not all,
Part of my blood runnes in thy tender veynes,
For those few drops I will not see the perish;
Be it for her sake whom once I lou'd,
And shall doe euer: Oh iniurious Stroza!
I now begin to feare; for this sweete Babe
Hath in his face no bastardy, but shewes
A Princely semblance: but Stroza and the Duke,
This will I keepe as charie as her honour,
The which I prize aboue the Vniuerse.
Though she were forc't to be unnaturall,
I'le take to me this Infants pupillage;
Nor yet resolu'd, till I a way haue found
To make that perfect which is yet vnsound.

div.head: Explicit Actus Secundus.
div.stage: Enter Milleine with Lords and Iulia.

sp.speaker: Milleine
sp.l: Forbeare my Lords for a few priuate words:
Faire Daughter, wee'le not chide you farther now
Nor adde vnto your blushes: by our rude
Reproofes your faults are couered with these your sighes,
Since all your fire of lust is quencht in ashes.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Durst I presume my Lord, to know
Whither you have send my sonne?

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: I'le not haue it question'd.
I striue to salue thy honour, and thou seek'st
To publish thy disgrace: my study is
Where I may picke thee out a noble Husband,
To shadow these dishonours, and keepe thee
From the like scandall.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Whom but Parmaes Prince.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Oh name him not thou strumpet.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: I haue done.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: There's a Prince of noble hopes and fortunes,
The Prince of Florence: what if I sent to him
About a speedy Marriage? for I feare,
Delay may breed strange doubts.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Since I haue lost the name of Child,
I am a seruant now and must obey.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Stroza.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Your eare my Lord, 'tis done.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Laid out?

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: To safety as I hope.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: What, and suspectlesse?

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Vnlesse the silent Groue of Trees should blabe,
There is no feare of scandall, mantled close,
I left the sucking Babe where the next passenger
Must finde it needes, and so it hapned for
Some two yeares after,
Passing that way to know where 'twas become,
'Twas gone, and by some courteous hand I hope
Remou'd to gentle fosterage.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: My excellent friend,
For this wee'le bosome thee: your counsel Stroza,
Our Daughter's growne to yeares, and we intend
To picke her out a Husband, in whose issue
Her name may flourish, and her honours liue:

sp.speaker: All Lords
sp.l: Most carefully deuis'd.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: But where my Lords
May we prouide a match to equall her?

sp.speaker: 1 Lord
sp.l: Ferrara hath a faire and hopefull Heire.

sp.speaker: 2 Lord
sp.l: And so hath Mantua.

sp.speaker: 3 Lord
sp.l: How do you prize the Noble Florentine?

sp.speaker: 1 Lord
sp.l: In fame no whit inferiour.

sp.speaker: 2 Lord
sp.l: But in state
Many degrees excelling: aime no further
Sir, if that may be accepted.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: To Florence then wee'le streight dispatch Embassadours,
Stroza, bee't your care to mannage this high businesse.
Oh to see
How Parents loue descends: and how soe're
The Children proue vngratefull and vnkinde,
Though they deride, we weepe our poore eyes blinde.

div.stage: Enter Clowne gallant, and the Huntiman.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: Nay, nay, the case is alter'd with mee since you saw me last: I was neuer in any hope to purchase any other suite then that I wore yesterday; but now I can say Ecce signum, the case is alter'd. Now euery begger comes vpon me with good Gentleman, good Gentleman: when yesterday Gentlemen would haue shun'd the way for feare I should haue begg'd of them. Then comes another vpon mee with good your Worship, good your Worship, then doe I double my fyles, and cast him a single two pence.

sp.speaker: Hunt.
sp.l: Sirrah, thou mayst thanke the Prince for this.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: Tnou say'st true; for he hath chang'd our woodden Dishes to Si uer Coblets: goodly large Arras that neuer yet deseru'd hanging, he hath caus'd to be hang'd round about the Chamber: My Lady and Mistresse, now my Lady and Mistresse lyes ouer head and cares in Downe and Feathers: well, if they be rui'd by me, I would haue them to keepe their beds.

sp.speaker: Hunt.
sp.l: Why wouldst thou haue them lye a bed all day?

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: Oh dull ignorant! I meane knowing how hard they haue bin lodg'd in the Forrest; I would not haue them sell away their beds, and lie vpon the boords.

sp.speaker: Hunt.
sp.l: Oh now I vnderstand you sir.

sp.speaker: Clow,
sp.p: Ey, ey; thou may'st get much vnderstanding by keeping my company: But Sir, does not the new Gowne the Prince sent my Mistresse, become her most incomparably?

sp.speaker: Hunt.
sp.p: 'Tis true: 'tis strange to see how Apparrell makes or maries.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: Right: for yeasterday thou wouldst haue taken me for a very Clowne, a very Clowne; and now to see, to see.—

div.stage: Enter Mother and the young Lady gallant.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.l: Sirrah.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.l: Madam.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: To see if the Tayler that made your Gowne, hath put ne're an M●vn●er your Girdle, there belongs more to beaten Sattin then sirrah.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: What thinke you Mother of the Prince his bounty,
His venue, and perfection?

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.l: He's a mirrour, and deserues a name
Amongst the famous Worthies.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Heighoe.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.l: Why sigh you?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Pray tell me one thing Mother: when you were
Of my yeares, and first lou'd, how did you feele
Your selfe?

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.l: Loue Daughter?

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: Shee talkes: Now, if shee should be enuamored of my comely shape; for I haue (as they say) such a foolish yong and relenting heart I should neuer say her nay, I should neuer weare off this stand further off.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Stand farther off sir.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.l: No, I'le assure your Ladiship 'tis beaten Sattin.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Then take your Sattin farther.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.l: Your Ladiship hath coniur'd me, and I will auoide
Satan.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Had you not sometimes musings, sometimes extasies,
When some delicate aboue other
Was present?

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.l: I aduise you curbe your sence in time,
Or you will bring your selfe into the way
Of much dishonour.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: And speake you by experience Mother? then
I doe begin to feare lest that his shape
Should tempt me, or his bounty worke aboue
My strength and patience; pray Mother leaue vs neuer,
Lest that without your Company, my loue
Contending with my weakenesse, should in time
Get of the vpper hand.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.l: For this I loue thee.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: So hoe Mistris Madam, yonder is the Prince, and two or three Gentlemen come riding vpon the goodliest Horses that euer I set my eyes vpon: and the Princes Horse did no sooner see me, but he weeighed and wagg'd his tayle: now I thinking he had done it to take acquaintance of me, said againe to him, Gramery Horse; so I left them, and came to tell your Ladiship.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Goe see them stabled, my soule leapt within me
To heare the Prince but named.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: Now my faire Friend.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Your hand-mayd mighty Prince.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: Looke Mounsieur,
Can she be lesse then Noble? nay deserues she
Thus habited, to be tearm'd lesse then Royall,
What thinkst thou Mounsieur?

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.l: Faith my Lord,
I neuer loue a woman for her habite,
When sir I loue, I'le fee my lone starke naked.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: Right courteous Lady,
Our bounty is too sparing for your worth,
Yet such as 'tis accept it.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.l: Royall Sir,
'Tis beyond hope or merit.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: I prithee Mounsieur,
A little complement with that old Lady,
Whilst I conferre with her.

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.l: I thanke you Sir:
See, you would make me a sir Panderus,
sp.stage: Hee talkes with the old Lady.
sp.l: Yet farre as I can see you, I will trust you.
Sweete Lady, how long is't— nay keepe that hand,
Since those fierce warres 'twixt Florence and great Millaine
Nay that hand still.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: And haue you ne're a loue then?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Yes my Lord:
I should belye my owne thoughts to deny,
And say I had none.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: Pray acquaint me with him,
And for thy sake I'le giue him state and Honours,
And make him great in Florence. Is he of birth?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: A mighty Duke-domes Heire.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: How now my Lauretta?
I prithee sweete where liues he?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: In his Countrey.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: Honour me so much
As let me know him.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: In that your Grace must pardon me.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: Must? then I will. Is he of presence sweete?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: As like your Grace as one Prince to another.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: Honour me so much then, as let me know him.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: In that excuse me Sir.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: Thee, loue I will
In all things: wherefore study you?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Why my Lord?
I was euen wishing you a mighty harme;
But pardon me 'twas out euen vnawares.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: Harme? there's none can come from thee Lauretta,
Thou art all goodnesse, nay confesse it sweete.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: I was wishing with my selfe that you were poore:
Oh pardon me my Lord, a poore, a poore man.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: Why my Lauretta?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Sir, because that little
I haue, Might doe you good: I would you had
No, money, nay, no meanes: but I speake idly,
Pray pardon me my Lord.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: By all my hopes
I haue in Florence, would thou wert a Dutchesse,
That I might court thee vpon equall tearmes;
Or that I were of low deiected fortunes,
To ranke with thee in Birth: for to enioy
Thy beauty, were a greater Dowre then Florence
Great Duke-dome.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.l: Oh my Lord, my Lord,
sp.p: Are you close at it? and you too crabbed Age, and you the— there's Rods in pisse for some of you.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: Now sir, the newes?

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.l: Oh my Lord, there's a Nobleman come from the
Court to speake with you.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: Mounsieur, vpon my life 'tis some Embassadour.

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.l: Good Sir make haste, lest I be challeng'd for you.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: No worthy Friend, for me thou shalt not suffer,
At our best leasur'd houres we meane to visite you;
Now giue me leaue to take a short fare-well.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Your pleasure is your owne,
To part from him I am rent quite asunder.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.l: And you can but keepe your leggs close,
Let him rend any thing else and spare not.

div.stage: Enter Florence and Lords with Stroza Embassadour.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Speake the true Tenor of your Embassie.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: If Florence prize the Duke of Millaines loue,
His indear'd Amity: If he haue minde
To mixe with him in confanguinity,
To strengthen both your Realmes: he make the proiect
To your faire Treaty, that your hopefull Heire
Shall with the princeise Iulia his faire Daughter,
Be ioyn'd in Marriage; her large Dowre shall be
A spacious Duke-dome after his decease.
But which my Lord counts most, is a faire League
'Twixt your diuided Duke-domes.

sp.speaker: Florence
sp.l: We doe conceite you:
But for the Dowre you craue?

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Ten thousand Crownes
By th'yeare.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: 'Tis granted: onely our Sonnes consent
Is wanting: but see here, he wisht for comes.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: Mounsieur what are those?

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.l: Embassadours my Lord.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: Whence are these Lords?

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: From Millaine.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: Their businesse Royall Sir?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: About a match,
Which if you't please, we highly shall applaud.
They offer you a faire and vertuous Princesse
Vnto your bed:

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: Vnto my bed my Lord?
I am not so affraide of spirits Sir,
But I can lye alone without a bed-fellow.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: 'Tis the faire Princesse Iulia you must Marry.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: Marry my Lord?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: I marry must you Sir,
Or you diuorce your selfe from our deare loue.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: But is she faire?

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: As euer Hellen was.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: What, and as Charte?

sp.speaker: Stroza.
sp.l: It were not Princely in you, Royall Sir,
To question such a Princesse Chastity;
I could haue instanc'd Lucrece.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: Would you had,
For both were rauisht.

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.l: How's this my Lord?
They offer loue and beauty, which being both
So freely offer'd, doe deserue acceptance,

sp.speaker: Stroza,
sp.l: Your answere Sir?

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: That I am yours:
The States; and if you please
So to dispose me, hers: what ere she be,
Come friend, I must impart my Loue this newes,
Or it will rend my heart.

sp.speaker: Stroza.
sp.l: I shall returne this answere.

sp.speaker: Florens.
sp.l: Faithfully
As we intend it: But you first shall taste
The bounty of our Court, with royall Presents
Both to the Duke your master, and the Princesse;
It done, prepare we for this great solemnity,
Of Hymeneall Iubilies. Fixt is the day,
Wherein rich Florens shall her pompe display.

div.stage: Enter Parma and a Lord of Millaine.

sp.speaker: Parm.
sp.l: Onely to you, of all the Millaine Peeres,
I dare expose my safety.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: In these armes
My Lord, you are Sanctuared.

sp.speaker: Parm.
sp.l: I doe not doubt it:
But I pray you tell me, since I left the Court,
How is my absence taken?

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Of the Duke,
With much distaste.

sp.speaker: Parm.
sp.l: But of the Princesse Iulia?

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: Full two Moneths
Shee kept her Chamber, grieuously distracted,
They say, meere griefe for your departure hence.

sp.speaker: Parm.
sp.l: Brauely manag'd,
The Duke I see was more kind to her fame,
Then to his prettie grand-childe; well Ile salt it all,
But what thinke you if after all I should
Send Letters to her, or Ambassadors?
I should not win her, for I know
Th'aue her heart in bondage.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: Why worthy Prince,
Haue you not heard the newes: Shee hath beene offered
Vnto the Florentine, the match accepted,
And the Nuptiall day the tenth of the next Moneth.

sp.speaker: Parm.
sp.l: No more: Pray leaue mee Sir.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: I will: Pray Sir
Regard your safety.

sp.speaker: Parm.
sp.l: To bee married, Ruimus in vestitum semper,
I did neglect her, but being deni'd,
I doate vpon her beautie: Methinkes 'tis fit,
If I begot the Child? I wed the Mother:
The Prince, I pitie hee should bee so wrong'd,
And I the Instrument: Now helpe mee braine,
That neare was wont to fayle mee: 'Tis decreed
Something to Plot, although I faile to speede.

sp.speaker: Clowne
sp.l: I wonder you should bee so sad and melanchollie,
Ile lay a yeeres wages before hand Ile tell your disease,
As well as any Doctor in Florence, and
Let me but feele your pulse.

sp.speaker: Lauret.
sp.l: Away, you are a foole, and trouble vs.

sp.speaker: Clowne
sp.l: That's no matter whether I bee a foole or a phisitian,
If I loose, Ile pay, that's certaina.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.l: Try the fooles counsell daughter, but bee sure
To forfit, and to pay.

sp.speaker: Lauret.
sp.l: Now sir, your skill.

sp.speaker: Clowne
sp.p: Nay, I must feele your pulse first, for if a Womans pulse bee neere a place, I know there's few heere of my yeeres but would bee glad to turne Doctors.

sp.speaker: Lauret.
sp.l: Now sir, you see I doe not smile.

sp.speaker: Clowne
sp.p: Nay, if it bee nothing else, Ile fetch that will cure you presently.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: Child I must chide you, you giue too much way vnto this humour: It alters much your beautie.

sp.speaker: Clowne
sp.l: Oh young Mistris, where are you, the Prince,
The Prince.

sp.speaker: Lauret.
sp.l: Oh Mother, doe you heare the newes, the Prince,
The Prince is comming. Where is hee, oh where?

sp.speaker: Clowne
sp.p: Where is hee? Why at the Court; where should hee bee? I did but doo't to make you smile: Nay, Ile tickle you for a Doctor: Madam I haue a yeeres wages before hand.

sp.speaker: Lauret.
sp.l: Is hee not come then?

sp.speaker: Clowne
sp.l: No marrie is hee not.

sp.speaker: Lawret.
sp.l: My soule did leape within, to heare the Prince
But nam'd: It started euery ioynt.

sp.speaker: Clowne
sp.l: Nay Madam, the Prince is come.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.l: Away, your foolerie's vnseasonable,
Weele not beleeue you.

sp.speaker: Clowne
sp.l: If you will not beleeue mee, will you beleeue these?

sp.speaker: Lauret.
sp.l: Welcome my Lord: And wherefore doe you sigh?

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: I figh Lauretta, cause I cannot chuse.

sp.speaker: Lauret.
sp.l: Nor could I chuse, should you but sigh againe.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: Ile tell thee Loue, strange newes: I must be married.

sp.speaker: Lauret.
sp.l: Married my Lord!

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: Why doe you weepe? You blam'd mee now for sighing: Why doe you melt in teares? Sweet what's the cause?

sp.speaker: Lauret.
sp.l: Nay, nothing.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: And as I told thee Sweete; I must bee married,
My Father and the State will haue it so;
And I came instantly to tell the newes
To thee Lauretta; As to one, from whom
I nothing can conceale.

sp.speaker: Lauret.
sp.l: Why should you grieue
For that? For I, my Lord, must haue a Husband too.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: Must you? But when's the day?

sp.speaker: Lauret.
sp.l: When's yours my Lord?

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: The tenth of the next moneth.

sp.speaker: Lauret.
sp.l: The selfe same day,
And selfesame houre that you inioy your loue,
My Princely Husband I must then inioy.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: But doe you loue him?

sp.speaker: Lauret.
sp.l: Not my selfe more deere.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: How happie are you aboue mee faire friend,
That must inioy where you affect? When I
Am tide to others fancies: It was your promise
That I should know him further.

sp.speaker: Lauret.
sp.l: You shall see him
That day, as richly habited as the great
Heire of Florence: But royall Sir, what's shee
That you must bed then?

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: 'Tis Iulia,
The Duke of Millaines daughter: Why change your Face?

sp.speaker: Lauret.
sp.l: That shee that hates mee most should liue to inioy
Him I affect best: O my ominous fate,
I thought to haue hid mee from thee in these desarts,
But thou dost dogg mee euery where.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: Looke to her safety, not for the Crowne
Of Florence I would haue her perish.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.l: Helpe to support her.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: Oh Friend, that I should change my Royaltie
To weaknesse now: I doe thinke this lodge
A Pallace, and this Beautious Mayden-head
Of greater worth then Iulia.

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.l: Come my Lord,
Lay by these idle thoughts, and make you ready
To entertaine your Bride.

sp.speaker: Parm.
sp.l: The Prince, the Prince,
I come to seeke the Prince, and was directed
Vnto this place.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: Thy newes.

sp.speaker: Parm.
sp.l: A Letter.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: Whence?

sp.speaker: Parm.
sp.p: Reade, the Contents will shew you; their eyes are from mee, and I must hence.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: The Millaine Princesse is betroathed; deflowred,
Not worthy of your loue, beleeue this true
Vpon a Prince his word; when you, shall bed her,
And find her flawd in her Virginitie,
You shall haue cause to thinke vpon his loue
From whom you had this caution;
But doe it with that Princely management,
Her honour bee not slandered: Hee that loues,
Admires, and honours you:
Where's hee that brought this Letter?

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.l: Fled my Lord.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: Poast after; bring him backe,
Could hee not set his hand to 't—
How now, the newes?

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.l: Hee's fled vpon a milke white Gennet Sir,
Seeming t'out strip the winde, and I— lost him.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: Thou hast lost mee quite.

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.l: What meanes this passions Sir?

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: Mounsieur reade there,
What will confound thee: Oh if shee bee vnchast!
Could they find none but mee to worke vpon.

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.l: It confounds mee my Lord.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: If shee bee Chast,
How shall I wrong her, to question her faire Vertues?

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.l: Right.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: But if shee bee not right? I wrong my Honor,
Which after marriage, how shall I recall?

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.l: 'Tis certaine.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: Yes: Oh how am I perplext!
Come, Ile to Court,
Ile not bee sway'd: Were shee a Potent Queene,
Where Counsell fayles mee, Ile once trust to spleene.

div.stage: Enter the Clowne with his Table-bookes.

sp.speaker: Clowne.
sp.p:
Let me see, the Prince is to bee married to morrow, and my young Mistris meanes to keepe a Feast in the Forrest, in honour of his wedding at the Court: Now am I sent as Caterer into the City to prouide them victualls, which they charg'd me to buy; no ordinary fare, no more it shall, and therefore I haue cast it thus; First and foremost, wee will haue— (yes downe it shall) we will haue a Gammon of Bacon roasted, and stufft with Oysters; And sixe Black-Puddings to bee serued vp in Sorrell-sops; A pickell'd shoulder of Mutton, and a surloyne of Beefe in White-broth, so much for the first course. Now, for the second, we will haue a Cherry-Tart cut into Rashers and broyled; A Custard Carbonado'd on the coales; A liue Eele
swimming in clowted Creame; And sixe Sheepes-heads baked, with the hornes peering out of the pasty-crust. The morrall is, because it is a wedding dinner.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: The ioyfull day's to morrow. Passe this plunge
And we are made for euer.

sp.speaker: Clowne.
sp.p: What, my old Polititian? hee that vndermin'd my old Lady and my yong Mistris? now that I could find but one stratagem to blow him vp; I would tosse him, I would blanket him i'th Ayre, and make him cut an Italian caper in the Clouds: These Polititians can doe more execution with a pen, in their studies, then a good Souldier with his sword in the field, but he hath spi'd mee.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: Thee friend I should haue knowne?

sp.speaker: Clowne.
sp.p: And you too, I should haue knowne, but whether for a friend, or no, ther's the question?

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: Thou seru'st the Generall Sforsa.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: I confesse it; but whether you haue seru'd him well, or no, there hangs a Tale.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: How doth thy noble Lady, faire Lauretta?
They haue left Millaine long, reside they here
Neere to the City Florence?

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: Some three miles off, here in the Forrest, not halfe an houres riding.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: I pray thee recommend me to them both,
And say, It shall goe hard with mine affaires
But Ile find season'd houres to visit them.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: You shall not want directions to find the place, come when you will, you shall be most heartily— poyson'd.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: Tell them, The newes that they are well
Is wondrous pleasing to me, and that power
I haue in Millaine is reseru'd for them,
To worke them into grace: I can but smile,
To see how close I haue plotted thier exile.
Now businesse calls me hence: farewell.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.l: And behang'd, Monsieur Stroza, whose description
My Muse hath included in these few lines;

q.l: Stroza, Thy Head is of a compely Block,
And would shew well, crown'd with the combe of Cock:
His Face an Inne, his Brow a sluttish Roome,
His Nose the Chamberlaine, his Beard the Broome,
Or like New-market Heath, that makes theeues rich,
In which his Mouth stands iust like Deuills-ditch

sp.l: And so farewell to your worship, graue Mounsieur Stroza,
For I must about my market.

div.head: Actus Quartus.
div.stage: A Dumbe shew. Enter at one doore, the Duke of Millaine, Iulia, Stroza, and a Bishop: At the other doore, the Duke of Florens, the Prince and Mounsieur, with attendants: Then the Bishop takes thier hands and makes signes to marry them, and then the Prince speakes.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: Stay till we be resolu'd.

sp.speaker: Florens.
sp.l: What meanes our sonne?

sp.speaker: Princ.
sp.l: Not to be gull'd by the best Prince in Europe;
Much lesse by Millaine.

sp.speaker: Millaine.
sp.l: Sir, be plaine with vs.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: I much suspect that Ladies Chastity.

sp.speaker: Millaine.
sp.l: Hers.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: I haue said.

sp.speaker: Stroza.
sp.l: Ther's Worme-wood.

sp.speaker: Millaine.
sp.l: I came in termes of Honour,
Brought with me, all my comforts here on earth,
My daughter; to bestow her on thy son:
Poore Lady, innocently comming, forsaking all,
Father and Countrey, to betake her selfe
Vnto his bosome; and is she for all this,
Branded with shame?

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: Who can acuse her, speake? what probabilities?
What ground? the place? the meanes? the season how
Shee did become corrupt?

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: Sir, so we haue heard.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: Produce the witnesse; and behould, I stand
The Champion for her honour, and will auerre
Her Chaste, aboue degree; infinitely honest:
Oh Prince! what, can you ground such iniury
Vpon vaine heare-say? Speake for your selfe, take spirit

sp.speaker: Iulia.
sp.l: Came we thus farre, to be thus wrong'd?

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: Was the slaue neuer Christen'd, hath hee no name?

sp.speaker: Iulia.
sp.l: Haue you sent for me, to accuse me heere
In this stange Clime? It is not Princely done.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: O Heauen, how am I perplext!

sp.speaker: Floren.
sp.l: Sonne, Sonne, you wrong
Your selfe and me too, to accuse a Lady
Of such high birth and fame; vnlesse you confesse
Your selfe to haue err'd, you needs must forfeit vs.

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.l: My Lord, yeeld to your father, lest you draw
His wrath vpon you.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: Well, since I must, I will:
Your pardon, Royall Father: Yours faire Princesse:
And yours great Duke:
If I shall find my self truely to haue err'd,
I shall confesse your chastity much iniur'd.

sp.speaker: Iulia
sp.l: Submission is to me full recompence.

sp.speaker: Milla.
sp.l: My daughters honour?

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: Doe not stand off my Lord,
If she be wrong'd, shee's not much behind-hand.

sp.speaker: Milla.
sp.l: Oh let me alone Stroza.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: Nay, good Brother
Accept him as your Sonne.

sp.speaker: Milla.
sp.l: My hearts no closet for reuenge; tis done.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Now heare my protestations: I receiue
This Ladies hand on these Conditions;
If you, my Lord, her father, or her selfe,
Know her selfe faulty, Oh confesse it here,
Before the Ceremonies fasten on me: for if hereafter
I find you once corrupted? by this right hand,
My future hopes, my Fathers royalty,
And all the honours due vnto our house,
He haue as many liues and heads for it,
As he hath Manners Castles, Liues and Towres;
It shall be worthy to be bookt in Chronicles
Of all strange tongues: And therefore beautious Lady,
As you esteeme a Prince his name or honour,
That youl be a Mecenas vnto vertue;
If in the least of these you guilty be,
Pull backe your hand.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: What if you find her chaste?

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: If chaste? she shall be dearer farre to me.
Then my owne soule: I will respect her honour,
Equall with that of my great Ancestours;
All this I vow, as I am Prince and vertuous.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: Then ioyne their hands.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Shee's mine: Set forwards then.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: All goes not well, This iugling will be found,
Then where am I then? would I were safe in Millaine.
Here Matchiuell th'wast hatcht: Could not the same
Planet inspire this pate of mine with some
Rare stratagem, worthy a lasting Character:
No, 'twill not be; my braine is at a non-plus,
For I am dull.

sp.speaker: Milla.
sp.l: Stroza.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: My Lord.

sp.speaker: Milla.
sp.l: Oh now, or neuer Stroza!

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: I am turn'd Foole, Asse, Iddeott; Are they married?

sp.speaker: Milla.
sp.l: Yes, and the Prince after the Ceremonie,
Imbrac'd her louingly.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: But the hell is,
That they must lie together, ther's the Deuill.

sp.speaker: Milla.
sp.l: And then—

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: And then we are disgrac'd and sham'd.

sp.speaker: Milla.
sp.l: Canst thou not help't man?

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: Why you would make
A man— midwife, woo'd you? I haue no skill.

sp.speaker: Milla.
sp.l: Stroza, awake, th'art drowsie.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: Peace, interrupt me not,
I ha'te: so to reuenge mee vpon her
Whom most I hate. To Strumpet her 'twere braue.

sp.speaker: Milla.
sp.l: Counsell aduise me.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: Youle make me mad my Lord:
And in this sweet reuenge, I am not onely
Pleas'd (with iust satisfaction for all wrongs)
But the great Prince most palpably deceiu'd.

sp.speaker: Milla.
sp.l: The time runs on,
Thinke on my honor Stroza.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: If youle eate grapes vnripe, edge your owne teeth,
Ile stay the mellow'd season, doo't your selfe,
Vnlesse you giue me time for't.

sp.speaker: Milla.
sp.l: But thinke with mine, on thine owne safety Stroza.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: Peace, giue me way my Lord, so shall the Prince
Bee palpably deceiu'd, Faire Iulia's honor
Most prosperously deseru'd, The Duke my master,
Freed from all blame, Wane hindred, Peace confirm'd,
And I secur'd; Oh I am fortunate
Beyond imagination!

sp.speaker: Milla.
sp.l: O deare Stroza,
Helpe now, or neuer!

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: Hee was a a meere Asse
That rais'd Troys Horse: 'twas a pritty structure.

sp.speaker: Milla.
sp.l: Oh mee!

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: Synon, a foole, I can doe more
With precious Gold, then hee with whining Teares.

sp.speaker: Milla.
sp.l: Oh my tormented soule!

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: Pray my Lord, giue mee
Fiue hundred crownes.

sp.speaker: Milla.
sp.l: What to doe with them man?

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: See how you stand on trifles; when our liues,
Your honour; all our fortunes lie a bleeding:
What shall I haue the Gold?

sp.speaker: Milla.
sp.l: Thy purpose preethee?

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: I know a desolate Lady, whom with Gold
I can corrupt.

sp.speaker: Milla.
sp.l: There are fiue hundred Crownes,
Snroza bethinke thee what thou vndertak'st,
Such an Act, would make huge Atlas bend his head
Vnto his heele.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: But say I cannot win her,
They bide the brunt of all, heere let them stay,
With these fiue hundred Crownes Ile poast away.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: Maddam, yonder's a Gentleman comes to speake with you in all hast.

sp.speaker: Lauret.
sp.l: Admit him in.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: Lady bee happy, and from this blest houre
Euer reioyce faire Virgin, for I bring you
Gold, and Inlargement; with a recouerie
Of all your former losse, and dignitie,
But for a two houres labour: Nay, that no labour
Nor toyle, but a meere pleasure.

sp.speaker: Lau
sp.l: Your words like musick, please me with delight,
Beyond imagination: Offered to vs?
Being exil'd our Countrey, and our friends,
Therefore good sir, delay not with long complement,
But tell these hopes more plaine.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: Haue wee not heere
Too many eares?

sp.speaker: Lauret.
sp.l: Wee would bee priuate sirra,
And therefore leaue vs.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: You haue seene the Prince of Florence?

sp.speaker: Lauret.
sp.l: Yes, I haue.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: Is he not for his Feature, Beauty, Goodnesse,
The most Compleate? So absolute in all things.

sp.speaker: Lauret.
sp.l: All this is granted.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: How happy doe you thinke that Lady then
That shall Inioy him? Nay, that shall bee the first
To prooue him,
And exchange Virginitie,
Were't not bright Lady a great happinesse?

sp.speaker: Lauret.
sp.l: I wish that nappinesse were mine alone,
Oh my faint heart: Passion ouer-swayes me quite,
But hide thy griefe Lauretta: Sir, you ' le make
Me fall in loue with him: Were I his equall,
I then should iudge him worthy of no lesse.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: Loue him: What's she doth not, if shee haue eyes?
Were I my selfe a Woman: I would lay
My selfe a prostitute vnto the Prince:
Shee is not wise that would refuse him Lady.

sp.speaker: Lauret.
sp.l: Good Sir bee briefe:
To what pray tends these speeches?

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: To thee sweete Lady: I offer all these pleasures,
Oh happie fate that hath selected mee
To be your raiser: Lady take this gold,
But that's not all: For there are greater honours
Prepared for you; the Duke of Millaine doth
Commend him to you: Iulia his daughter
Hath in her honour late miscarried,
Now 't lies in you to salue and make all good.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Who? Lies this in my daughter?

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: Yes, in her,
Shee hath the power to make the Duke her friend,
Iulia her sister, and all Millaine bound
To offer vp for her thier Orrisons.

sp.speaker: Lauret.
sp.l: Good Sir bee plaine.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: This night lie with the Prince
In Iulia's stead: There's way made for you,
Who would not woo, for what you are wooed too?

sp.speaker: Lauret.
sp.l: Doe you not blush, when you deliuer this
Praye tell the Duke, all Women are not Iulia,
And though wee bee deiected, thus much tell him,
Wee hold our honour at too high a price,
For Gold to buy.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: Nay Lady, heare me out;
You shall preserue her honour, gaine the Duke,
Redeeme your fortunes: Strengthen you in friends,
You shall haue many Townes and Turrets standing,
Which future Warre may ruine: Thinke on that.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Lauretta, oh behold thy mothers teares!
Thinke on they Father, and his honour wonne,
And call to mind our exile: All the wrongs
Wee haue indured by her, to whom wee gaue
No cause, and now are plundg'd in a deepe streame.
Which not resisted, will for euer blemish
The name of Sforsa thy great Ancestors,
Thou'lt waken thy dead Father from his graue,
And cause his honour'd wounds which hee receiu'd
From that vnthankfull Duke, to bleede afresh,
Powring out new blood from 's grisly wounds,
If thou consentest to this abhorred fact,
Thy Mothers curse will seaze on thee for euer:
Oh child, behold me on my knees: Ile follow thee,
Oh doe not leaue me thus, and pull on thee
An euerlasting staine, to scandall all
Thy former Vertues, for the momentarie
Short pleasures of one night.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: She doth not councell well; 'tis foolish rashnes,
Womanish Indiscretion

sp.speaker: Lauret.
sp.l: Sir bee answered,
If Iulia bee disloyall: Let her bee found
So by the Prince she wedds: Let her be branded
With the vile name of strumpet: Shee disgrac'd
Mee, that nere thought her harmes; publikely strucke mee,
Nay in the Court: And after that, procur'd
My banishment: These Iniuries I reap't
By her alone, then let it light on her.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: Now see your errour,
What better; safer, or more sweete reuenge,
Then with the Husband? what more could woman aske?

sp.speaker: Lauret.
sp.l: My blood rebells against my reason, and
I no way can withstand it: 'Tis not the Gold
Mooues mee, but that deere loue I beare the Prince,
Makes me neglect the credit and the honour
Of my deare Fathers house: Sir, what the Duke desires
I am resolued to doe his vtmost will.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Oh my deare daughter.

sp.speaker: Lauret.
sp.l: Good Mother speake not, for my word is past.
And cannot bee recall'd, Sir will you away?
I am resolute.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: Shee yeeldes vnto her shame; which makes me blest,
Let Millions fall, so I bee crown'd with rest.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Oh me, vnhappie, that here knew griefe till not.

div.stage: Musicke. A Dumbe Shew. Enter Millaine, to him Stroza, and brings in Lauretta masked, the Duke takes her and puts her into the Bed, and Exit.
Enter both the Duke and Iulia, they make signes to her and Exit: Stroza hides Iulia in a corner, and stands before her.
Enter againe with the Prince to bring him to bed; They cheere him on, and others snatch his Pointes, and so Exit. The Dukes Imbrace, and Exeunt.

div.head: Actus Quintus.

sp.speaker: Milla.
sp.l: Thou art our trusty Counsellor; if this passe 〈◊〉
We're past all feare: What is she preethee? What?

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: What's that to you, bee shee what ere she can,
All's one to vs, so she be found a Virgin;
I haue hyred her, and shee's pleas'd.

sp.speaker: Milla.
sp.l: But gaue you charge
Assoone as ere the Prince was fast asleepe,
That shee should rise and giue place to our daughter?

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: Doubt you not that; what, iealous already?

sp.speaker: Milla.
sp.l: How long she stayes, I faine would be a bed;
Pray heauen shee doe not fail
By him asleepe, and so forget her selfe.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: Heer's in my heart, a violent Feauer still;
Nor shall I find my selfe in my true temper,
Vntill this brunt bee past.

sp.speaker: Milla.
sp.l: What, not yet? had she with Parma beene a bed so long,
It would haue more perplext mee.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: See, here shee is;
The newes?

sp.speaker: Lauret.
sp.l: The Prince is fast, all done.

sp.speaker: Milla.
sp.l: Step in her place;
Nay when? and counterfeit sleepe presently.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: Away to bed my Lord: You to the Forrest.
I'le to my Coach, all's well.

sp.speaker: Lauret.
sp.l: And for my part, it was not much amisse,
Because my Lord the Prince had such content
Which caus'd him giue his Charter to my hand,
The full assurance of faire Iulia's dowre:
Day gins to breake, and I must to the Lodge.
Oh what a griefe it was to leaue the Prince!
But leaue those thoughts: These Gifts to me assign'd,
Are nothing worth the Iem I left behind.

div.stage: Enter Prince and Mounsieur with a Torch.

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.l: What doe you not like your bed-fellow, my Lord;
That you are vp so soone?

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Oh friend, was neuer man blest with a Bride
So chast! I'me fearce my selfe, till this be knowne
To my faire Forrest friend: Lett's mount away,
The nights quite spent; and now begins the day.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: And what was it you said sirra?

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.l: Marry, I would intreat your Lady-ship to turne away
My fellow Ierom, for I thinke hee's
No true man.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.l: No true man, Why?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Marry we were both in the Tauerne together tother day—

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.l: And hee stole some Plate?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: No Madam, but there stood at our elbow a pottle Pot—

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.l: And hee stole the Pot?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: No Madam, but he stole the wine in the Pot, and drunke it off,
And made himselfe so drunke hee be-pist himselfe:
Your Ladyship could not be better be-pist in a Summers-day.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Good morrow Lady: Wher's your daughter pray?

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.l: Shee tooke so little rest last night, my Lord
I thinke shee is scarce well.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Pray may wee see her?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: My Lord you may.

div.stage: Shee's drawne out vpon a Bed.

lg.head: Song.
lg.l: HEnce with Passion, Sighes and Teares,
Desasters, Sorrowes, Cares and Feares.
See, My Loue (my Loue) appeares,
That thought himselfe exil'd.
Whence might all these loud Ioyes grow?
Whence might Myrth, and Banquet's flow?
But that hee's come (hee's come) I know.
Faire Fortune thou hast smil'd.
Giue to these blind windowes, Eyes;
