Daze the Stars, and mocke the Skies,
And let vs two (vs two) devise,
To lavish our best Treasures
Crowne our Wishes with Content,
Meet our Soules in sweet consent,
And let this night (this night) bee spent
In all aboundant pleasvres.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: Oh good morrow Lady,
I come to tell you newes!

sp.speaker: Lauret.
sp.l: They are wellcome to me my Lord.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: You know the Princesse Iulia was suppos'd to bee Adulterate—

sp.speaker: Lauret.
sp.l: So we haue heard it rumor'd

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Oh but faire friend, she was indeed bely'd!
And I this morning rose from her chast bed:
But wherefore sweete cast you that blushing smile?
But you haue broak promise with me: For you told me
That the same day and houre I took my Bride,
You should Inioy a Princely Husband.

sp.speaker: Lauret.
sp.l: Trew
My Lord, I did.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: And are you married then?

sp.speaker: Lauret.
sp.l: And lay with him last night.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Is hee oft fortunes?

sp.speaker: Lauret.
sp.l: That you may soone coniecture by this gift.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: What haue you then, some tokens that were his?

sp.speaker: Lauret.
sp.l: Some few my Lord, amongst the rest, this diamond
Hee put vpon my finger.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: You amaze mee!
Yet Rings may bee alike: If then your husband
Bee of such state and fortunes, What dowre are you allotted.

sp.speaker: Lauret.
sp.l: Sir, ten thousand crownes by th' yeere.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: I gaue no more vnto my Iulia.
But where is the security you haue
For the performance of it?

sp.speaker: Lauret.
sp.l: See here, My Lord,
Sir, Is not that sufficient for a dowry?

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: This is the Indenture that I gaue to Iulia;
Preethee Lauretta, but resolue me true,
How came you by this Charter?

sp.speaker: Lauret.
sp.l: Pardon great Prince; for all that loue you spake
To Iulia, you whisper'd in my eare:
Shee is vnchast; which, lest you should haue found,
Her father sent mee here, fiue hundred crownes
By Stroza; but neither his gold, nor all
His sly temptations, could one whit mooue mee;
Onely the loue I euer bare your honour,
Made me not prise my owne. No lust full appetite
Made me attempt such an ambitious practise,
As to aspire vnto your bed my Lord.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Rise, dee not weepe, Oh I am strangely rapt
Into deepe strange confusion?

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.l: Millaine should know, were it my case my Lord,
A better Prince then hee should not wrong me.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: I haue bethought already how to be are mee;
This Charter and this Ring, faire Loue, keepe you;
And when I send for you, you shall repaire
Vnto the Court: This all I shall inioyne you.

sp.speaker: Lauret.
sp.l: Great Sir, I shall.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Come Mounsieur, now 'tis cast,
Reuenge neere rules, so it be found at last.

div.stage: Enter the two Dukes with Iulia, Stroza and attendants.

sp.speaker: Milla.
sp.l: Who saw the Prince last? Is't a custome with him
To rise thus early?

sp.speaker: Floren.
sp.l: Sir, hee neuer sleepes
Longer then th'day, nor keepes his bed by Sunne:
'Tis not the lone of the fairest Lady liues,
Can make him leaue his morning exercise.

sp.speaker: Iulia
sp.l: He neuer exercis'd with me, I'm sure;
I might haue layne as safe, free, and vntoucht,
By any Lady liuing.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: Pardon Lords,
I haue stay'd you long, your blessing royall Father.
My custome is, euer to rise before
A womans houre: Now heare me speake my Lords,
I'm married to a Lady, whose chaste honour,
Reports and false Suggestions, did inforce me
To call in publike question; but that we leaue
Vnto our last nights rest.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: True my good Lord;
But did you find me faulty?

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: I doe protest, my Lords, I bosom'd with
As true and chaste a Virgin, as ere lodg'd
Within a Princes armes; All this I vow
As I am Royall.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: All's well my Lord?

sp.speaker: Milla..
sp.l: All's excellent Stroza.

sp.speaker: Prin..
sp.l: Now for amends and publike satisfaction,
For the foule wrong I did her, questioning
Her Vertue, Ile confirme her dowre, and that
Before I eate: Sweet Lady, reach the Charter
I gaue you last night, 'fore you were full mine?

sp.speaker: Iulia
sp.l: I receiu'd none Sir.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Sweet, will you tel mee that?
With which you did receiue a Ring the Duke
My father gaue me.

sp.speaker: Iulia
sp.l: When?

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: Last night.

sp.speaker: Iulia
sp.l: Where?

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: In your Bed.

sp.speaker: Iulia
sp.l: 'Twas in my dreame then.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: Being broad awake.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: I like not this: I smell a Rat.

sp.speaker: Milla.
sp.l: Stroza, I feare too.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: Brazen fore-head, Wilt
Thou leaue now: 'Tis true my Lord. You did
Receiue them both, Haue you forgot sweet Lady,
This very morning, that you gaue them both
To me? The Princess ieasted, to see how
You woo'd but take it.

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.l: Excellent Villaine!

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: 'Twas well put off:
'Tis strange shee's so forgetfull: I prethee Stroza
Where are they?

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: Where are they? they are—

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: Where?
Why studdy you?

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: They are there—

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: Where man?

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: I poasted them
To Millaine, sent them safe, dare you not trust my word

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: Not till I see my deeds.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: By one oth' Princes Traine.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: See which o' the Traine is wanting.

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.l: I shall my Lord.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: I would I were in Turkey.

sp.speaker: Milla.
sp.l: Would I were on horse-backe.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Nay, looke not you deiected beautious Bride,
For this is done onely to honour you.

div.stage: Enter a Seruing-man with a child in a couered Dish.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: The Prince, my Master, hearing your solemnities,
Hath sent this dish, to adde a present to
Your royall Feasts, wishing himselfe therein
To be a wellcome guest.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: Your Masters name?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Prince Parma.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: Giue this Gentleman
A 100. crownes: This will much grace our banquet.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Ther's in that dish, some Morrall.

sp.speaker: Milla.
sp.l: Comming from him,
Meethinks it should be season'd with some strange
And dangerous poyson: Touch't not, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: There should be more in't, then a feasting dish;
What's here, a Child?

sp.speaker: Iulia
sp.l: Oh my perplexed heart!

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Vpon his brest ther's something writ, Ile read it.
'Tis fit, if Iustice bee not quite exil'd
That he that wedds the mother, keepe the child.
This Child was sent to me.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: From whom? whom, Parma? breake the bastards necke,
As I would doe the Fathers, were hee here.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Sure spare't for the Mothers sake; t'was sent to vs:
Which of the trayne is wanting?

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.l: None my Lord.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Stroza, where is this Charter and the Ring?

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: I know of none.

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.l: Why, t'was confest.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: Right, I confest it; but your grace must know,
'Twas but to please your humour, which began
To grow into some violence.

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.l: I can forbeare no longer; Impudent Stroza,
Thou art a Villaine, periur'd, and forsworne:
That Duke dishonourable; and shee vnchast:
Besides, thou hyredst a Virgin in her roome;
(Slaue as thou art) to bosome with the Prince;
Gau'st her fiue hundred Crownes. That this is true,
I will maintaine by combat.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: That I did this? Hee lies below his entrayles,
That dares to braue mee with such a proud affront:
And in the honour of my Prince and Countrey
I will approoue thee recreant.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: A strife, that nought saue combat can deside,
The cause so full of doubts, and intricate.
See, they are both arm'd, and euenly, without odds,
Saue what the iustice of the cause can yeeld.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Bee't no intrusion held, if a strange Prince
(Setting behind, all complementall leaue)
Amongst strange Princes enters: Let me know
Which is the Prince of Florance?

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: Wee are hee.

sp.speaker: Parm.
sp.l: And Parma?

sp.speaker: Iult.
sp.l: Parma?

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: Excuse mee Sir,
I know him not: But if I much mistake not,
Wee are late indebted to you for a present.

sp.speaker: Parm.
sp.l: It was a gift, I should bee loath to part with,
But vpon good conditions. Am I then
To all a stranger: Doe you not know mee Lady?

sp.speaker: Milla.
sp.l: Heare him not speake, I charge thee by thine honor?

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: Parma speake, and if thy speech was bent to mee?

sp.speaker: Parm.
sp.l: Ere I proceede, let mee behold this babe;
Nere a Nurse heere? Pray hand it you sweete Lady,
Till I find out a Mother.

sp.speaker: Milla.
sp.l: Touch it not,
I charge thee on my blessing.

sp.speaker: Iulia
sp.l: Pardon Sir,
It well becomes my handling.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: Parma proceede.

sp.speaker: Parm.
sp.l: Then Florence know, thou hast wrong'd me beyond, thought;
Shipwrackt my Honour, and my Fame; nay strumpeted
Her, whom I tearme my Bride.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: 'Tis false, I neuer imbrac'd saue with one,
And her, I found to bee most truely chast.

sp.speaker: Parm.
sp.l: Then It maintaine: Hast thou a Wife heere?

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Parm.
sp.l: Then Ile approoue her to bee none of thine,
That thou hast fetch't her from anothers armes.
Nay more, that shee's vnchast?

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Know Parma, thou hast kindled such a Flame,
That all the Oceans billowes scarce can quench:
Bee that our quarrells ground.

sp.speaker: Florence
sp.l: Princes, forbeare:
First see the Issue of the former Combat,
Before more blood you hazard.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: Wee are pleased.

sp.speaker: Parm.
sp.l: And wee content.

div.stage: Enter Stroza and the Mounusieur, they fight, and Stroza is ouercome.

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.l: Yeeld thy selfe recreant villaine, or thou dy'st.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: Saue mee, I will confesse; Is Parma heere?

sp.speaker: Parm.
sp.l: Yes, heere wee are.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: I falsely stuft thy head with Iealousies,
And for some priuate ends of my reuenge,
Disgrac'd the Generall, and set odds betwixt
Lauretta and the Princesse: All these mischiefes
Proceede from my suggestions.

sp.speaker: Milla.
sp.l: Damne him for it.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: Is that your kindnesse? Giue me leane to liue,
Bee't but to taynt his honour.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: Tell mee Stroza,
Was Iulia chaste?

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: Did her Father know it?

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: Yes, and more too: I had the Gold from him,
To bribe the Generalls daughter.

sp.speaker: Florence
sp.l: Iniuries,
Beyond the thought of man.

sp.speaker: Milla.
sp.l: Which wee ' le no longer striue with, since the heauens haue laid that ope most plaine and palpable, which most wee thought to conceale.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: Will Parma fight?

sp.speaker: Parm.
sp.l: Resolue mee first? Was Iulia found Chast?

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: I heere protest, wee parted both, as cleere,
As at our first encounter.

sp.speaker: Parm.
sp.l: Then I accept her, If you my Lord
Bee pleas'd so to part with her.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: Willingly.

sp.speaker: Iulia
sp.l: Now haue I my desires: Had I withall,
The Princely babe I boare.

sp.speaker: Parm.
sp.l: See Iulia,
Whom thy hard-hearted Father doom'd to death,
My care hath still Conserued, Imbrace it Lady;
Nay, 'tis thy owne nere feare it.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: Then Prince Parma,
With your words Ile proceed.
'Tis fit all Iustice hee not quite exil'd,
That hee that wedds the Mother keepe the child.

sp.speaker: Florence
sp.l: But Peeres, the Virgin that this Stroza hired
To Iustifie thee wrongs?

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: At hand my Lord:
Mounsieur conduct them hither?

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.l: I shall Sir.

sp.speaker: Milla.
sp.l: The Generalls Wife and Daughter.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.l: Yes and their man too; all that's left of him.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: This the Maide,
To whom I am so bound?

sp.speaker: Laure.
sp.l: Oh let me lie
As prostrate at your foot in Vassallage,
As I was at your pleasure.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: Sweete arise.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: Your Lordship hath bin vp already, when shee was downe: I hope if the thing you wott of goe no worse forward then it hath hegun, and that you take charge of my young Lady, you neede not bee altogether vnmindfull of her Gentleman-Vsher.

sp.speaker: Florence
sp.l: Of what birth is that Lady?

sp.speaker: Milla.
sp.l: Euen the least
Enuy can speake, Shee is a Souldiers Daughter,
Decended from a noble parentage.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Who with her mother,
Thus kneeles to him, as to their Soueraigne.
Intreating, grace and pittie.

sp.speaker: Milla.
sp.l: You haue both:
Sure, sure, the heauens for our Ingratitude,
To noble Sforza, our braue generall,
Hath sau'd crost our proceedings: which to recompence,
Wee'le take you vnto our best patronage.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Millaine is honorable.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: But by your fauour Sir,
This must bee our owne charge.

sp.speaker: Florence
sp.l: With which we are pleas'd.

sp.speaker: Iulia.
sp.l: Stroza was cause of all, but his submission
Hath sau'd him from our hate, arise in grace.
Whil'st we thus greete Lauretta.

sp.speaker: Lauret.
sp.l: Royall Princesse,
I still shall be your hand-maide.

sp.speaker: Stroza
sp.l: Who would striue,
To bee a villaine, when the good thus thriue?

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: You crowne me with your wishes, Royall father;
My Mistris first, and next my bed-fellow,
And now my Bride most welcome. Excellent Sir,
Imbrace the Millaine Duke, whil'st I change hand
With Princely Parma; Iulia, once my Wife?
Backe to your husband I returne you chast:
Mounsieur, bee still our friend: You our kind Mother:
And let succeeding Ages, thus much say:
Never was Maiden-head better giuen away.

lg.l: NEw Playes, are like new Fashions; If they take?
Followed and worne: And happy's hee can make
First into 'th Garbe: But when they once haue past
Censure, and proue not well, they seldome last.
Our Play is new, but whether shaped well
In Act or Seane, Iudge you, you best can tell:
Wee hope the best, and 'tis our least of feare,
That any thing but comely should shew heere;
Howeuer Gentlmen, 'tis in your powers,
To make it last; or weare out, in two houres.
